instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.3V42_G3H: What is 3V42_G3H? This is shorthand for PP3V42_G3H which is one of the first power rails that must turn on in older Macbooks that use a magsafe charger in order for them to get a light on the charger. This power rail powers the onewire circuit and the SMC, which are necessary for the machine to communicate with the charger and get it to turn on, as well as begin the bootup sequence. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL: What is PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL? This is the voltage coming directly from the charger after going through a transistor. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.R7105: What is R7105? resistor between charger and CHGR_DCIN pin of ISL6259, if CHGR_DCIN is low then this resistor is probably blown. When PPBUS_G3H is low or missing this is something to check if your model has CHGR_DCIN along R7005. .
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.C7125: What is C7125? Capacitor between CHGR_BOOT and CHGR_PHASE important for bootstrapping creation of PPBUS_G3H on 2013-2015 macbook pros.
definitions.D7105: What is D7105? Diodes between PPDCIN_G3H charger voltage and CHGR_DCIN pin of ISL6259, when CHGR_DCIN Is low(less than charger voltage) and PPBUS_G3H is missing this is a critical point to troubleshoot.
definitions.TPS51980: What is TPS51980? This is a power chip responsible for the PP3V3_S5,  PP5V_S5,  and PP5V_S3 power rails on many A1286 Macbook Pros,  A1297 Macbook Pros,  A1369 Macbook Airs,  A1466 Macbook Airs,  A1370 Macbook Airs,  and A1465 Macbook Airs.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No charge light PP3V42 present
threads.message:
Hi all,

i bought another donor board off eBay to have a look at last week. 3437 which has no PP3V42 or PPbus shorts. In fact PP3V42 is present but I’m not getting a green light on the charger. There is sever corrosion on <CAPACITOR>C3740</CAPACITOR>, <RESISTOR>R3741</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R3742</RESISTOR>. <CHIP>U3740</CHIP> looks ok though but I’ll probably replace it to be safe. Issue is both pads for <CAPACITOR>C3740</CAPACITOR> and <RESISTOR>R3742</RESISTOR> and one pad for <RESISTOR>R3741</RESISTOR> are completely gone and <RESISTOR>R3742</RESISTOR> is now reading ground on both ends.

I saw a slight amount of corrosion on pin 8 of <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> but upon removal it seems fine so I’m hoping that was just surface junk.

Question is can the board boot without the above 3 mentioned pads intact? I’m not fussed about internal ssd I can always use a USB dock but I’m not sure if those are going to be required for boot or not. Unfortunately I do not have any donor boards to substitute these parts so it’s back to the Ali express waiting game.

thanks!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No charge light PP3V42 present
threads.message:
"<RESISTOR>R3742</RESISTOR> is now reading ground on both ends."
Remove <CHIP>U3740</CHIP> and check if short disappears.
However, it is not important in the power on sequence; unless <CHIP>U3740</CHIP> doesn't short <SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> to ground.

Post basic voltages of <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>; pins 1, 2, 3, 9, 12, 13, 14, 15, 17, 19, 20, 27.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No charge light PP3V42 present
threads.message:
Thanks. <RESISTOR>R3742</RESISTOR> still reads ground on both sides after removing <CHIP>U3740</CHIP>. Pin 1 on <CHIP>U3740</CHIP> is slightly corroded but otherwise looks fine. I've left it off theboard for now. 
ISL Pin readings with a donor installed: 
 pin 1: 15.27, pin 2: 16.22, pin 3: 16.15, pin 9: 0, pin 12: 3.42, pin 13: 3.37, pin 14: 0.02, pin 15: 0.046, pin 17: 0, pin 19:0 , pin 20: 0, pin 27: 0.391

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No charge light PP3V42 present
threads.message:
"pin 3: 16.15"
There is a problem; probably open (corroded) <RESISTOR>R7111</RESISTOR>.
Check all resistors and traces around <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>.
Be sure no corroded caps; pay atention to <CAPACITOR>C7100</CAPACITOR>/01.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No charge light PP3V42 present
threads.message: Is there a way to tell if a dc in board is good or not? Besides trying a known working board as I don’t have one.  I unfortunately don’t have any other dc in boards nor do I have a working board to test this one on. Looks clean. Tried to find a board view for the dc in board but it looks like they are not available yet, and the ones that are look completely different. We’re getting 3v42 but i don’t think that means the dc in boards 100% working.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No charge light PP3V42 present
threads.message:
I asked to do something on the MLB.
Why do you concern about DCIN board at this moment?
You must get correct <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> even without LIO flex.

Fix the problems in <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> area first!!!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No charge light PP3V42 present
threads.message:
Because I haven’t done much of this so I have no idea what can cause what? I was just asking if the dc in board could be giving me what I’m seeing. 

Ok now pin 3 on the ISL is 4.3V. <RESISTOR>R7110</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7111</RESISTOR> had some ugly joints so I've touched it up. Both and the cap are reading as they should and do not look damaged.All components are present and look physically ok bar <RESISTOR>R7102</RESISTOR> which is noted as no stuff in the schematic. Diode measurements for <CAPACITOR>C7101</CAPACITOR> .448 c100 .447 Though if i connect the charger there getting no voltage. <CAPACITOR>C7142</CAPACITOR> isn’t reading short but it’s not getting any voltage.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No charge light PP3V42 present
threads.message: Can you post the actual voltage for all mentioned pins???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No charge light PP3V42 present
threads.message:
Ok I've remeasured this time at the corresponding components rather than the pins of <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>. See below:
pin 2 use <CAPACITOR>C7105</CAPACITOR>: 15.15V
Pin 3 use <RESISTOR>R7111</RESISTOR>: 4.32V
Pin 9 use <RESISTOR>R5431</RESISTOR>: 0.030V
Pin 12 use <CAPACITOR>C7102</CAPACITOR>: 3.42V
Pin 13 use <RESISTOR>R7100</RESISTOR>: 3.38V
Pin 14 use <RESISTOR>R5187</RESISTOR>: 0V
Pin 15 use <RESISTOR>R5422</RESISTOR>  0.047:
Pin 17 Use <CAPACITOR>C7150</CAPACITOR>: 0V
Pin 19 use <RESISTOR>R7101</RESISTOR>: 5.08V
Pin 20 use <RESISTOR>R7101</RESISTOR>: 5.08V
pin 27 use <CAPACITOR>C7120</CAPACITOR>: 0.0206V

All the small resistor/caps around the SMC look ok as well as does the SMC, so they should not be pulling down the lines the SMC shares with the ISL.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No charge light PP3V42 present
threads.message: You've forgot pin 1, which is very important.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No charge light PP3V42 present
threads.message: Sorry just didn't paste it. Pin 1 is 15.31V. Is 4.32 too high for pin 3? According to Logiwiki their example had pin 3 as 3.81 and the threshold minimum is 3.2 so I'm thinking 4.32 is too high but than checking all the components on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL</SIGNAL> which controls that line are matching their values so I'm puzzled as to why it's so high. I also tried removing F7140 and checking which side if any are short, but the CPU side is in the millions of ohms and the other side is in the K of ohms range. Diode modes were .7 and .18 respectively. Injecting voltage revealed nothing really, the caps on that line got slightly warm but only very mildly and they read non short so seem fine.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No charge light PP3V42 present
threads.message:
"the CPU side is in the millions of ohms and the other side is in the K of ohms range. Diode modes were .7 and .18 respectively"
Can you explain this?
Where do you get mohm to ground, if diode mode is 0.180, or 0.700???

 STOP to inject voltage into <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> in such manner!!!
Read the forum and will understand why.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No charge light PP3V42 present
threads.message: Pin 1 with the fuse removed is .1117 & pin 2 is .453 Pin one resistance is reading all over the place, it starts at Millions than dips down to 30K than resets starts at 10K and goes up to 32K than rinse and repeat. I think I need to replace this meter I'm constantly having to change the battery to get it to read values that make sense.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No charge light PP3V42 present
threads.message:
Diode mode readings look good; why do you need to check in ohm mode???
Only switch to ohm mode for very low readings in diode mode, as 0.010 for exmaple.

Pin 1 voltage is bad; should be 0V.
Change <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> and be sure to have good solders and traces.
Also check resistance between its pins 17/18 and 27/28.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No charge light PP3V42 present
threads.message:
Ok fair enough. I’ve had a lot more experience with resistance values than diode mode hence why I was referencing both as I wasn’t exactly sure whether .1 would be considered low or not, but I do know that K ohms usually is normal operation.

ok I tried re installing <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> to make sure it’s soldered properly but no change. I’ll have to order one as the one on there now is off a donor board. I’ll re install the original one first see if values change or not than I’ll order a new one if needed.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No charge light PP3V42 present
threads.message:
Be aware, if you talk about 0.1(100 mOhm) in Ohm scale, that means pure short; unless you specify, KOhm, or MOhm as unit.
0.1 (0.100) in diode mode, is totally different thing; could be 100-200 Ohm in resistance mode, depending of multimeter used.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No charge light PP3V42 present
threads.message: Thanks for the clarification. Not sure if this is relevant or not but I removed the donor ISL and measured it's pins 17 to 18 and 27 to 28 and there 4.8 ohm on the donor ISL. All the measurements previously provided were from this donor ISL. I then did the same on the original ISL the board came with and that's 4.6 for pin 17 to pin 18 & 4.71 on pins 27 to 28. I'm reinstalling this ISL now and will check pin one hopefully it will now be zero otherwise I'll have to wait for a new one to arrive. I had a quick google hoping someones posted the pin measurements on a known working ISL but unfortunately couldn't find anything.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No charge light PP3V42 present
threads.message: I've reinstalled the original ISL and now pin 1 is resetting. First time you put your probes on it it's .5V than climbs to 1 than 2 than 11 than 15 and resets. Doesn't look like it's the ISL, it looks like it's trying to do it's job but somethings resetting it or it's resetting itself because it's faulty.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No charge light PP3V42 present
threads.message: Yay I'm finally getting somewhere. Just noticed pin 2 on the ISL was only 4.2V. Checked <RESISTOR>R7105</RESISTOR> and it was in the K ohm range when it's suppose to be 20 ohm. Replaced it, confirmed it's is now 20 ohm and pin 2 is back to 15.15V and pin 1 is now 0.004V so it looks like the ISL is finally working and pulling down <SIGNAL>CHGR_AGATE</SIGNAL>. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> at the fuse is now a happy 8.56V. <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> is 5.15V so now I just need to go down the list and see what's missing. Curious what happened to <RESISTOR>R7105</RESISTOR>, as it was not originally blown and as you can see above pin 2 was originally 15.5V as it is now and back then I was missing PPBUS and also <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>. I guess the donor ISL was faulty indeed and replacing it with the original overheated <RESISTOR>R7105</RESISTOR> or something.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No charge light PP3V42 present
threads.message: Is <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4SW_SNS</SIGNAL> a required rail for the board to post? It's 0v and not short. A lot of the items on that rail are not installed on the board like the camera area and the current sense area. <CHIP>U5440</CHIP> for example and it's surrounding components. According to the schematic there critical but checking my 3437 and 165 donor boards there also missing them so I'm thinking their no stuff despite not being labeled as such and labeled critical instead.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No charge light PP3V42 present
threads.message:
First, to clarify your confusion.
Amazing to heard you checking between <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> pins out of board!!!
I just hope you will do that ONBOARD next time.
We needed to know the resistance of <RESISTOR>R7120</RESISTOR>+21+22 and <RESISTOR>R7150</RESISTOR>+51+52 respectively; not internal chip resistance.

Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS voltages now?
The board has any reaction when pulsing power button?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No charge light PP3V42 present
threads.message:
Yes <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> are present.  Yes shorting the power debug switch pulls the reset line low and is resetting the SMC.
 .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No charge light PP3V42 present
threads.message:
What switch, what reset line???
PLEASE, use signal names!!!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No charge light PP3V42 present
threads.message: <RESISTOR>R5115</RESISTOR> <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> I don't have a keyboard deck hence why I used that instead.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No charge light PP3V42 present
threads.message:
"and is resetting the SMC"
What this means?
You've checked some signal, Isuppose.
Can we know which is???

<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> should NOT reset SMC.
You make some confusion there!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No charge light PP3V42 present
threads.message: I checked both <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMC_S5_PWRGD_VIN</SIGNAL> and both were dropping to 0 when shorting <RESISTOR>R5115</RESISTOR>. Is there a particular line I should check? I wanted to check a few other SMC outputs but they were missing, ie 0V. WIFI enable  on SMC pin 63 for example.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No charge light PP3V42 present
threads.message:
If charger is connected, S5 voltage MUST be steady.
Did you test the board alone on the desk?

When trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>, you should note a drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> (at same time).
Be sure <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is stable (all the time); no reaction at <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> allowed.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No charge light PP3V42 present
threads.message: Yes <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> Is steady 3.33V. Yes board has only been tested on the desk nothing plugged into the board, besides the DC in board obviously. Everything else is either removed from the board, or did not come with the board as this is a ebay "untested" job.  <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>  is 3.41V steady. 0.357V When I short <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>. <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is 3.38V and shorting <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> does not change it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No charge light PP3V42 present
threads.message: Something on the ISL line most be shorted as the ISL is now getting really hot when it was not earlier. That explains why the original failed, but none of the immediate surrounding components are reading short nor getting hot only the ISL itself.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No charge light PP3V42 present
threads.message: Looks like I've got another dead ISL. Checked all the components around it and they all seem fine. Checked which pins do not go to components in the area and checked them and there also fine. The only one which is short is ISL pin 24 <SIGNAL>CHGR_UGATE</SIGNAL> pin 1 of <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>. Confirmed on two donor boards that's not suppose to be short. Removed it but the lines still short and there are no other components on that line.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No charge light PP3V42 present
threads.message:
Bad <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>?
Replace <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> and <CAPACITOR>C7125</CAPACITOR> at same time.
Check resistance between pins 17/18 and 27/28.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No charge light PP3V42 present
threads.message: Ok <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>, <CAPACITOR>C7125</CAPACITOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> have been replaced. Pin 1 on <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> is now reading 330K ohm. Resistance between pin 17/18 is 3 ohms and resistance between 27/28 is 19.8ohm.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No charge light PP3V42 present
threads.message: ISL is still getting really hot, and looks like <RESISTOR>R7105</RESISTOR> is blown again. Not as much as before though, now it's only gone up to 70 ohm.Pin 1 on <RESISTOR>R7105</RESISTOR> is reading OL. Replaced <DIODE>D7105</DIODE> now pin 1 on <RESISTOR>R7105</RESISTOR> was reading but I didn't note it down and now when I go to measure it jumps between .367M and OL. Diode mode just reads OL. Is there any other components on the 3437 or 165 that we can use as a temporary replacement for <RESISTOR>R7105</RESISTOR>? I've already stolen that exact resistor off both my 3437 and 165 donors and searching for a 20 ohm 603 resistor for both schematics came up with nothing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No charge light PP3V42 present
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7105</RESISTOR> can only get burnt because of <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>, or <CAPACITOR>C7105</CAPACITOR>; did you change that cap?
You can use 4.7-27 ohm for <RESISTOR>R7105</RESISTOR>, without problems.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No charge light PP3V42 present
threads.message: Thanks I do have some 4.7 ohm so I'll use that for now. Yes <CAPACITOR>C7105</CAPACITOR> was changed, though it was from a donor board so it may of been damaged though it did not read short nor does it now. Is it worth changing the mosfet <TRANSISTOR>Q7155</TRANSISTOR>? I was always taught when changing fets you should always change the pair and their controller. Also for <TRANSISTOR>Q3005</TRANSISTOR> is it normal for it to have a slight brass colour to it? It's measuring fine but it does have that "i've been extremely hot in the past" look to it. Though both my donor boards have the same tinge to them so it's hard to tell if that's just normal or not.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No charge light PP3V42 present
threads.message:
Remove F7140 and check <CAPACITOR>C7140</CAPACITOR> voltage.
Resolder all good components first.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No charge light PP3V42 present
threads.message: Ok I reflowed the whole ISL area & I replaced <CAPACITOR>C7105</CAPACITOR> again. I used <RESISTOR>R7700</RESISTOR> on my 3437 donor as a replacement for <RESISTOR>R7105</RESISTOR>. pin 1 <RESISTOR>R7105</RESISTOR> is now reading 60K ohm .445 diode mode. Same on pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R7105</RESISTOR>. Removed F7140 <CAPACITOR>C7140</CAPACITOR> voltage is 0V. The battery is not plugged in though, that should only have voltage if the battery is connected should'nt it? PPDCIN @ <CAPACITOR>C7130</CAPACITOR> is 16V but at F7140 we have nothing on both sides.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No charge light PP3V42 present
threads.message:
If no voltage at <CAPACITOR>C7140</CAPACITOR>, removing F7140, then the problejm is on <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> area for sure.
Keep the fuse out and post basic voltages for <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>; pins 1, 2, 3, 9, 12, 13, 14, 15, 17, 19, 20, 27.
Use surrounding components as test points!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No charge light PP3V42 present
threads.message:
I'm awaiting more ISLs, I think the ones I got are dodgy and <RESISTOR>R7105</RESISTOR> has blown again twice with these "new" ISLs. I used a 10 ohm is the power rating important? I used a 1/16 10 ohm as it was the closest I had to the 1/10W 20 ohm. I've buldozed the whole ISL section and replaced everything and now am waiting for new ISLs to arrive. Something keeps blowing <RESISTOR>R7105</RESISTOR>, and I'm suspecting it's because the line off pin 1 is reading OL

What should diode mode read on <CAPACITOR>C7116</CAPACITOR>? On one donor and this board I have OL on the test pad, OL on pin 1 and 0.122 on pin 2. On another donor I have the same bar pin 2 which is 0.46. Seems a bit low 0.122.

I blew away <CAPACITOR>C7116</CAPACITOR> can <CAPACITOR>C3294</CAPACITOR> be used as a replacement? I don't have anymore 470PF 16V closest I have is 330 like <CAPACITOR>C3294</CAPACITOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No charge light PP3V42 present
threads.message:
1/16W is less power than 1/10W; so 1/10W should be better even to use.

Did you check diode mode on pin 2 of <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>, w/ and w/o <CAPACITOR>C7105</CAPACITOR>?

You can try 330pF instead of 470pF for <CAPACITOR>C7116</CAPACITOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No charge light PP3V42 present
threads.message: Pin 2 on <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> is 0.449 with <CAPACITOR>C7105</CAPACITOR> and 0.445 without. Thanks, I'm using 330pf for <CAPACITOR>C7116</CAPACITOR> till my extra donors arrive. <RESISTOR>R7105</RESISTOR> is reading 23 ohms when it is a 10 ohm resistor and was reading 10 ohms when I installed it which is weird. If it was blown you would expect it to go a lot higher than just double it's value? Pin 3 on <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> is now reading dead short, 0.00 diode mode and 1 ohm resistance to ground. I got two ISLs with my last order, not sure if I should try the second one or not since the first one seemed dodgy this one probably is as well.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No charge light PP3V42 present
threads.message:
Remove <CAPACITOR>C7111</CAPACITOR> and check again diode mode at pin 3.
If still short, bad <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No charge light PP3V42 present
threads.message:
Ok I replaced  <CAPACITOR>C7105</CAPACITOR> and <RESISTOR>R7105</RESISTOR> again and tried the second ISL and same thing again. Pin 1 on <RESISTOR>R7105</RESISTOR> has 16V pin 2 nothing. <CAPACITOR>C7105</CAPACITOR> nothing on both sides. <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> pin 1 at the test pad is 5.46V.

Pin 3 is no longer reading short, looks like it was the ISL again causing that though I replaced all 3 on that line just in case. Pin 6 on <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> is the only thing reading low ish now. .068 or 100 ohm. Is that suppose to be so low? 

A short pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R7105</RESISTOR> could could also cause it to fail couldn't it? I'm starting to think something on that side may be causing it since everything on the pin 1 side has been replaced multiple times. <RESISTOR>R7190</RESISTOR> for example looks pretty ugly but it's only reading 1 ohm in circuit so if that was blown it should be higher than that considering it's suppose to be 0 ohm. Could it possibly be <CHIP>U7190</CHIP>? I don't believe I have replaced that yet, nor most of the components on the <SIGNAL>PP5V1_CHGR_VDDP</SIGNAL> line. <RESISTOR>R7101</RESISTOR> is reading bang on what it should be 4.7 ohm but that does not mean there's not a issue on that rail.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No charge light PP3V42 present
threads.message:
"Pin 6 on <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> is the only thing reading low ish now. .068 or 100 ohm. Is that suppose to be so low?"
Didn't see <RESISTOR>R7113</RESISTOR>???

Did you check diode mode to ground at pin 2 of <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>, before applying power to the board?

Your board uses <CHIP>U7190</CHIP>?
It is marked as NO STUFF in schematic.
<RESISTOR>R7190</RESISTOR>/91 also souldn't be there...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No charge light PP3V42 present
threads.message:
No I saw <RESISTOR>R7113</RESISTOR> just thought that line should be higher than that. 

I did, I didn't note it down though. When I replaced all the components on the <RESISTOR>R7105</RESISTOR> pin 1 side and replaced the ISL last, I re checked all the components surrounding the ISL on each of the ISL pins to make sure nothing was reading short, which nothing did bar pin 6 which while not technically short did make me question why it was seemingly a low value.

Sorry, made a bit of a typo there. No <CHIP>U7190</CHIP> is not there, only components populated in that area are <RESISTOR>R7190</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7191</RESISTOR>. I think it was the <CHIP>TPS51980</CHIP> that I mistook for <CHIP>U7190</CHIP> since it looked like there was a tiny bit of green to the right side pins but very faint hard to tell. But that cant be the issue as none of the lines around the ISL go to the TPS? 

Are you sure <RESISTOR>R7190</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7191</RESISTOR> are marked as no stuff in your schematic? Mine there not, most other components are but there not. Page 70 of 120.  
Confused as to why <RESISTOR>R7105</RESISTOR> keeps blowing when there are only 3 components on that line, and they have all been replaced multiple times. Do we have a pin out on diode mode readings both board side and of the ISL itself? I had a quick google search but couldn't find anything. That would help rule out a ISL issue.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No charge light PP3V42 present
threads.message: If you solder <RESISTOR>R7190</RESISTOR>, it will inject DCIN voltage into 5V LDO of <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>; a good reason to fry it...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No charge light PP3V42 present
threads.message:
Ah that explains why the ISLs keep dying then. <RESISTOR>R7190</RESISTOR> has always been there. This was your typical ebay " don't know what's wrong with it we haven't touched it" listing, so they have obviously tried to repair it and saw it was not listed as no stuff and placed it there. Curious that it's not listed as no stuff in my schematic though. Which one are you using? I got mine from the usual place, badcaps. I've also got Zin Zhi Zao which also does not list it as no stuff. 

If the ISL was shorted though you should be able to pick that up by testing the pads on the chip itself shouldn't you? Pin 2 is shorted at pin 2 of <CAPACITOR>C7105</CAPACITOR> on the board but when I remove the ISL and re test the short is gone. But than I diode mode the chips pin 2 to ground you get .602

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No charge light PP3V42 present
threads.message: Replaced the <CHIP>TPS51980</CHIP> as it did look a bit suspect. <RESISTOR>R7105</RESISTOR> is not blowing anymore is it looks like it was <RESISTOR>R7190</RESISTOR> causing the issue. ISL is getting hot now so yay gotta order some more ISLs. This time I'll order more than two....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No charge light PP3V42 present
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7190</RESISTOR> is marked like optional, in case of "PP5V5__DCIN:YES" version; never faced with such board.

<CHIP>U7100</CHIP> should have some reason to get hot.
Inspect all its surrounding components; <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> is suspect now.
Check diode mode to ground at L7130.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No charge light PP3V42 present
threads.message: L3170 pin 1 .138 pin 2 .138. <TRANSISTOR>Q3170</TRANSISTOR> pin 1 .138. <CAPACITOR>C7125</CAPACITOR> pin 2 .137. All values are diode mode. Looking around the ISL immediate area will report back once completed, just thought I should do these first as <TRANSISTOR>Q3170</TRANSISTOR> was originally the issue so likely is the issue again. Removed <CAPACITOR>C7105</CAPACITOR> again as it was causing my meter to read OL on pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R7105</RESISTOR>. Can it be left off just for testing purposes? I do not have any other 50V caps to use.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No charge light PP3V42 present
threads.message:
You can leave off <CAPACITOR>C7105</CAPACITOR>.
Be sure <CAPACITOR>C7125</CAPACITOR> is in place.

I hope you've refered to L/<TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>, not 3170...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No charge light PP3V42 present
threads.message: Yes <CAPACITOR>C7125</CAPACITOR> is in place and reading fine. Sorry typed, yes I meant L/<TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>. Everything at the top immediate area of the isl is reading ok as is the left side. I’ll go through the rest tomorrow.
